intro: Melandrium andicola, commonly known as the Andean bladderpod, is a flowering plant native to the Andes region of South America. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbage plants, and is characterized by its small, cruciform flowers. The plant typically grows in high-altitude grasslands and rocky areas, adapting to the harsh environmental conditions of its habitat. Its leaves are usually narrow and hairy, and it produces small, round pods that contain seeds. Melandrium andicola is of interest to botanists due to its unique adaptations and potential ecological roles in its native environment.
